In order to achieve that, the spacecraft will perform seven flybys of the planet Venus, in order to slowly lower its closest approach to the sun. In January of this year, it passed 19.4 billion meters from the Sun, and it will perform this same flyby in June. In December 2025, the probe will achieve its closest flyby, which is 6.9 billion meters from the Sun’s center or 6.2 billion meters from the Sun’s surface. This is only 9 solar radii away from the Sun, and reach 430,000 miles per hour, or 6% or our target speed.As other answers have pointed out, the first hurdle to achieving 1% of the speed of light is the matter of fuel energy density. Chemical propulsion is nowhere near dense enough to get close, the fastest speeds achieved by chemical rockets is the launch of the New Horizons probe, about 36,400 miles per hour, and that was using an Atlas V, one of the most powerful rockets currently in service. In order to achieve 1% of the speed of light, we’ll need more efficient and more powerful forms of propulsion, and there are quite a few that you could choose from, far too many to mention here.The next hurdle is acceleration. We as humans can only survived sustained g-forces for so long before you start encountering organ failure, you actually reach the point where the structures inside us will literally be torn apart. Accelerations from fractions of 1 g (Earth surface gravity), up to about 2 to 3 g’s would probably be sustainable for a decent amount of time, from months at fractions of g to about 1 to 2 g, from days or hours perhaps of 3 g or so. Once you get into the higher accelerations, the kind usually only experienced in amusement park rides for fractions of a second, or in maneuvers in high speed aircraft, then you get down to less than several hours. Even higher accelerations would require even smaller time frames in order to be survivable. The highest acceleration ever survived by a human being was 46.2 g, and that was only for a fraction of a second.That being said, it wouldn’t take that much acceleration to get to 1% of the speed of light. If you wanted to accelerate at a comfortable 1 g, it would take 305,810 seconds, or 3.51 days. The distance traveled while accelerating at 1 g for that long is just over 4 times the average distance between the Earth and the Sun. If you accelerated five times faster, or 5g, it would only take 61,652 seconds, or 17 hours, and you would only travel about 62% of the average Earth-Sun distance.As other answers have pointed out, a major problem with traveling at these velocities is debris. This is a problem even with current space travel, and we travel much slower. As you get faster and faster, the relative velocity of debris gets larger and larger, and even the smallest of particles can eventually get deadly. Imagine a grain of sand hitting a target at 3 million meters per second. The kinetic energy of such a projectile would be 1.35 mega Joules, or about the same amount of kinetic energy of a Chevy Tahoe traveling at 67 miles per hour. What makes the grain of sand hitting you even worse than the truck hitting you is that the grain of sand has an incredibly small area. This is what allows small, fast moving projectiles to punch through materials that would easily stop a truck. Any reasonable solution to this problem adds mass, and thereby decreases how quickly you can accelerate to 1% of the speed of light, and also how far you can go based on the amount of fuel you have.Another consideration that needs to be made that other answers have touched upon is that you have to slow down in order to arrive at your destination, unless the destination is traveling at 1% of the speed of light. This is why the most time efficient way of traveling between any two points in space with constant acceleration involves accelerating towards the target for half the journey, and decelerating for the second half. This turns navigational problems into less a consideration of how fast you can get, which in space is rather meaningless, since any object given enough time, acceleration, and fuel can get up to some ridiculously fast speeds, but more a consideration of max acceleration. With a decent long term constant acceleration, you can get anywhere in the inner solar system within a week, anywhere in the solar system in a month, maybe two depending on orbital position. The Moon is about 3 and a half hours, about the same as a long regional flight, say London to Athens.
